customer_name: Ervin Miller Marcus Miller Anna May Miller
site_name: Ervin Miller Marcus Miller Anna Mary Miller

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
The licensee was unable to locate the written Exercise Program and current written Contingency Plan. These are two
required records that help demonstrate compliance with the Animal Welfare Act and are required to be available for
inspection. Ensure these documents are located or obtain/develop new copies as required for future inspections.
***Correct by February 19, 2024.

A M Shih-tzu (#41) was noted as disappeared 10-5-23 on the adult record of acquisition. The licensee said it had been
tethered by the greenhouse away from the other dogs that day due to compatibility but a couple hours later it had slipped
the collar off and was gone. Per the licensee they (licensee/neighbors) have not seen it since. Temporary tethering of
dogs as a primary enclosure does not provide for dogs' safety and is not approved as use for primary enclosure unless
approval is obtained from APHIS.
***Maintain correct from 1/29/2024 forward.

The licensee said a new veterinarian visited in the fall for dog physical exams and they will have a new attending
veterinarian (AV), however a written program of veterinary care (PVC) that is approved and signed by the new attending
veterinarian (AV) from the fall visit was not available for inspection. A written PVC that is approved by the current AV is
important to ensure dogs and puppies are getting adequate veterinary care. Ensure that a written PVC is developed,
documented in writing, and signed by the current attending veterinarian.
***Correct by 2/23/2024.

The licensee said that that complete physical exams were completed on each adult dog this fall, possibly in
September/October and a record sheet was left by the attending veterinarian, however the record sheet could not be
located and wasn't sure if the record sheet described physical exam results.
Medical records for animals help demonstrate that appropriate husbandry and treatment practices are being followed.
Facilities must keep medical records for their dogs and have the records available for inspection.
Contact the attending veterinarian to see if a copy of the physical exam records can be obtained and ensure to maintain
medical records for each dog.
***Correct by February 12, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.126(a)(2) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
The licensee was unable to locate the written Exercise Program and current written Contingency Plan. These are two 
required records that help demonstrate compliance with the Animal Welfare Act and are required to be available for 
inspection. Ensure these documents are located or obtain/develop new copies as required for future inspections.  
***Correct by February 19, 2024. 
3.6(c)(4)  Critical
   
Primary enclosures. 
A M Shih-tzu (#41) was noted as disappeared 10-5-23 on the adult record of acquisition. The licensee said it had been 
tethered by the greenhouse away from the other dogs that day due to compatibility but a couple hours later it had slipped 
the collar off and was gone. Per the licensee they (licensee/neighbors) have not seen it since. Temporary tethering of 
dogs as a primary enclosure does not provide for dogs' safety and is not approved as use for primary enclosure unless 
approval is obtained from APHIS. 
***Maintain correct from 1/29/2024 forward. 
3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee said a new veterinarian visited in the fall for dog physical exams and they will have a new attending 
veterinarian (AV), however a written program of veterinary care (PVC) that is approved and signed by the new attending 
veterinarian (AV) from the fall visit was not available for inspection. A written PVC that is approved by the current AV is 
important to ensure dogs and puppies are getting adequate veterinary care. Ensure that a written PVC is developed, 
documented in writing, and signed by the current attending veterinarian.  
***Correct by 2/23/2024. 
3.13(b)(1) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs.

The licensee said that that complete physical exams were completed on each adult dog this fall, possibly in 
September/October and a record sheet was left by the attending veterinarian, however the record sheet could not be 
located and wasn't sure if the record sheet described physical exam results.  
Medical records for animals help demonstrate that appropriate husbandry and treatment practices are being followed. 
Facilities must keep medical records for their dogs and have the records available for inspection. 
Contact the attending veterinarian to see if a copy of the physical exam records can be obtained and ensure to maintain 
medical records for each dog. 
***Correct by February 12, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
